Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: How Military Service and benefits Shapes STEM Career Trajectories

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
The project will advance scientists' understanding of STEM career trajectories by exploring the historical and contemporary role of the U.S. military as a potential career pathway. Specifically, the project analyzes the impact of educational benefits associated with military service (GI Bill), plus the role of individual and workplace factors on people's educational and occupational outcomes. Thus, the project addresses recurrent calls from the Federal Government and National Academy of Sciences to increase the number of STEM professionals, diversify the STEM workforce, and optimize the recruitment of military personnel. Findings from this project will help social scientists identify the long-term effects of policies and workplace dynamics on degrees and occupations. Findings will promote national defense and our ability to train the next generation of STEM scientists, because employers (from Departments of Defense and Commerce, Veterans Administration, to private-sector) are interested in hiring individuals with a military background, many of whom are poised to work in technical/defense fields and classified environments. Findings also will inform efforts to broaden STEM participation and identify potentially unanticipated consequences of federal policies designed to broaden access to higher education.

The project addresses the following questions central to scientific literatures on education and occupations: How does military service and the educational benefits associated with it shape individuals? subsequent training and employment in STEM fields? How have era of service and changing GI Bill benefits affected STEM trajectories among veterans? How do organizational factors associated with specific military branches facilitate entry into STEM fields? How does using competing definitions of STEM fields employed by federal agencies affect the form and magnitude of the above patterns? To answer these questions, the project employs statistical analysis of publically available secondary data from the American Community Survey (ACS) and Department of Defense Demographic Reports. The result will be a newly merged public-use data set available to researchers that combines Census data with organizational data on the armed services. Analyses involve sophisticated statistical models on large samples: For instance, analyses of occupational trajectories include more than 5 million ACS respondents, including more than 700k veterans. ACS data also facilitate analysis of educational and occupational patterns among active-duty military personnel, who potentially constitute a prime target population for recruitment into STEM fields. The project also makes a methodological contribution by examining how various, competing ways to operationalize and measure "STEM" used by federal agencies shape conclusions about the scope and extent of the much-discussed shortage of STEM workers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview. Military service is known to help many people become upwardly mobile, including first-generation college students, women, rural and ethnic minorities. This project examines whether military service creates this effect by shaping educational and occupational outcomes, particularly in STEM fields. The project addresses three related research questions: (1) Is there a relationship between military service and STEM degrees earned? If so, is it gendered and/or marked by intersectional dynamics?  (2) Is there a relationship between military service and STEM occupational outcomes? If so, is it gendered and/or marked by intersectional dynamics?  (3) Has military service been related to these outcomes for multiple generations, or cohorts, of veterans and active-duty personnel?  In addition, the project examines how our understanding of these connections between military service and educational or occupational outcomes shifts when we define “STEM” in different ways, either applying it to just a narrow set of fields (engineering and computer science) or using broader definitions (e.g., include health and other sciences). To address these questions, this project relies primarily on multiple years of U.S. Census data from the American Community Survey.

Main Findings: Intellectual Merit. Regarding degrees earned, findings suggest that military service is associated with higher odds of completing a STEM degree. This association is particularly strong for female veterans, especially if they are Latina or white. Comparing multiple STEM definitions shows that military service does not simply channel women into traditionally female-dominated STEM fields. Instead, the biggest boost exists for women veterans earning degrees in traditionally male-dominated STEM fields. Regarding occupational outcomes, results indicate that military service is also positively associated with STEM occupations. This means veterans overall, but especially women veterans, are more likely to work in STEM than similar civilians. Contrary to common sense, even veterans without STEM degrees are more likely to hold STEM occupations than their civilian peers. Indeed, even veterans without college degrees outpace their peers in STEM employment, which suggests that practical experiences gained in the military impact subsequent job outcomes.  Cohort analyses confirm that the relationship between military and STEM outcomes has grown stronger over time, opening the door for future research evaluating the relative impacts of access to and/or use of G.I. Bills as well as changes in labor markets on STEM trajectories.  The researchers discuss these findings in terms of their downstream implications for efforts to recruit and retain a diverse set of people in a wide range of STEM fields.

Main Findings: Broader Impacts. The federal government, employers, and expert organizations like the National Academy of Sciences have long advocated that the country needs to increase the number of STEM professionals and diversify the STEM workforce. Findings from this project have been featured widely in US media accessed by the general public and may inform efforts by the Departments of Defense, Education, and Commerce to achieve the above-mentioned goal. Findings can also inform interventions by the Veterans Administration and employers committed to helping former members of the military integrate into civilian society.  Given the large number of former and active-duty service members in the Armed Forces, this study provides a unique opportunity to optimize efforts to broaden STEM participation.

Outcomes to Date:

Steidl, Christina, Regina Werum, Sela Harcey, Jacob Absalon, and Alice MillerMacPhee. 2020. “Soldiers to Scientists: Gender, Military Service, and STEM Degree Earning.” Socius. Phttps://journals.sagepub.com/doi/full/10.1177/2378023120948713
